nodes.bodyText: how many of these will be there? would it be worth introducing a 'reader' method forgetting the DMN contents from separate files and keeping those separately?

There will be no more. They are mocked data for when the UI is ran against a mock backend, api-mock.
The real service will exist in trusty-service and is part of https://issues.redhat.com/browse/FAI-215.
I don't think there's much value added in improving the mock endpoint here.
I agree with @manstis
please adapt to #329

nodes.bodyText: Please reach to me whenever you have time regarding the UI testing and writing testable components.

I think there are no obvious advantages from using React.FC. It does type checking for propTypes and defaultProps, which we hardly use with typescript. It has an implicit definition for children (with an issue), but it's probably clearer to explicitly declare children anyway when a component relies on it.
There's no much difference in the end when using or not using React.FC.
Regarding destructuring props inside the signature, it's just a personal preference. I find it more readable to have it inside the body.
please try to refrain from having multiple return statements.
Fixed to use a single return.
no snapshot for the component?
Snapshots added.
I'd argue for keeping the top part of the component definition for props and component definition, can you move this either below or elsewhere?
I agree. Moved them to the bottom.
can't this be rather a component? otherwise I would expect for the file not to be placed under components (at least not having a separate skeletonRows folder there)
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,35 @@
+import React from 'react';
+import { IRow } from '@patternfly/react-table';
+import SkeletonStripe from './../../Atoms/SkeletonStripe/SkeletonStripe';
+
+/*
+ * Based on a number of rows and columns, this function creates an array specifically intended
+ * for the Patternfly Table component. Feeding the skeletons array to the table rows prop,
+ * it will produce animated stripes to be displayed while loading real data
+ * */
+
+const skeletonRows = (

nodes.bodyText: I was unsure about where to place it. Unfortunately it cannot be a component, given how PatternFly Table handles rows content. I moved it to the utils folder.
nodes.diffHunk:

+ * it will produce animated stripes to be displayed while loading real data
+ * */
+
+const skeletonRows = (

nodes.bodyText: previously the props were type, now interface, is there anything preventing us from unifying?
Switched to types for consistency.
Done. I am used to avoid using nested spread because it could get difficult to read. This example is simple enough I think.
move component definition to the top of the file
Done.
I'd argue to have just a single JSX Table element here and just prepare the columns and rows variables that would be passed there.
Done.
can we set the type to the const data declaration already?
Done.
it actually does not render the skeletons, so mount might be needed instead of shallow.

nodes.bodyText:
I thought it was enough to be sure of setting up the table with the right data configuration.
I avoided mount because we would end up rendering the whole PatternFly Table, which could be out of scope for this test. The snapshot would also contain dozens of thousands of lines, that are difficult to review when something changes.

nodes.bodyText: You can change this type do "success" | "failure", for example. <ExecutationStatus result={"success"} /> seems more semantic than <ExecutationStatus result={true} />
I agree. Done.
Done.
This should be wrapped in a useMemo.
This should be wrapped in a useMemo.
This should be wrapped in a useMemo.

I am sure there were some default styles before. Forgot to cleanup.
Done without nullish coalescing. The version of TypeScript we use doesn't support it yet. We are gradually updating everything. Now it's the turn of PatternFly. TypeScript could be next. I am considering updating it just for the trusty package to avoid refactoring though.
This should be wrapped in a useMemo.
datePicker can never be falsy (you can see that from its type), you can only check for datePicker.current
You have a point. Done.
Done.

This looks like an unexpected side effect. Every time this file is imported, this code will run, which is very hard to control and predict. It this change in configuration is important to your app, you should have an explicit call to a method that does that. On your application entry-point, you can call a function that executes this code. This way, it will be easier to understand why and when things were modified.

Moved the configuration in the app initialization. I didn't dwell too much with this datepicker implementation because it was meant to be temporary while waiting for the release of the PatternFly one in June. Unfortunately it was not released like planned.
These images should be in their own file. You can use Webpack to load SVGs as strings if you need.
Done.
This should be wrapped in a useCallback.
This should be wrapped in a useCallback.
Done.
You can either inline that or wrap it in a useMemo.
Done.
This should be wrapped in a useCallback.
This should be wrapped in a useCallback.
This should be wrapped in a useMemo.
This should be wrapped in a useMemo.

Since these parameters are all of primitive types, I feel like this custom Hook should have its signature improved by forcing "named parameters". If you create an object with these parameters, users will have to explicitly type the parameter name (which is only the property names of the parameter object). This will increase readability on places using this Hook.
I agree. I was used to some ESLint rule that warned you from adding more then 3 parameters to functions. Done.
You can inline this function call so you don't have to practically repeat the list of dependencies on the useCallback statement.
I am not sure about it. I am exporting the callback because it's needed for refreshing data. I am afraid I cannot inline it.
Nice use of the isMounted variable check. If I can push a little bit, maybe you can create a custom Hook for all request types, so that you don't have to repeat this logic for every request.
This is just a suggestion, though. I think it would improve readability of code making requests.

Yes, I've been thinking about it. I am moving ajax calls inside dedicated hooks while migrating the code for the PR's and it could help. I am also thinking about getting rid of the auditApi.ts wrappers if every ajax call will be confined in its custom hook. It seems a useless abstraction now.
I see you reformatted the code here without changes. Could it be that you're not using Prettier as the formatter? I see that you have prettier configured for this repository. Please check that.
Probably index.css was not formatted on the first PR for some reason. Maybe I did not set Prettier to run on .css files from the start. Now it does.
Any particular reason for these not be called Execution and Executions?
No particular reason. I was following some common pattern of prefixing interfaces with I. Which honestly I don't like. Changed as suggested.
You can inline that.
Done.

I think this function can be inlined. This indirection causes code reading to be more difficult, since its a code of your application, people will expect extra-behaviour. Instead, this is only an "alias" for axios.isCancel.
I am afraid I cannot inline it because it depends on the Axios instance. For now it's just an alias. It will eventually be gone with the custom hooks I was referring in the previous comment.
Since you're importing axios directly from the library, I think you could simply do that in other places too, but if you already have plans to improve that in the future, I'm ok with that atm :)
Cannot do optional chaining with the available version of TypeScript, sadly.
Oh :( Ok.
This is a global variable. We should avoid that at all costs, since they can be dangerous. Can you explain why you need this to be global?
I agree a module scoped variable is not the best solution. I will rewrite that together with the Axios handling I mentioned in the following PR.
Ok, thx for letting me know!
these snapshots seem redundant as we're checking the span content below.

I added them following your comment above 😬
I agree they are redundant. Should I remove them all?
Ah! My bad. I am sorry. Is there any benefit in let's say keeping just a single snapshot check? So that we notice the possible change in how component is rendered, but keep the snapshot file small.
Ok, let's keep the first one, just to track eventual PatternFly updates on the tooltip.
Is this a distinction between Tuesday and Thursday? (that's the only possible explanation I could come up with) Shouldn't similar workaround apply to Saturday vs. Sunday?
Yes, that's the reason. I don't know how I overlooked the same thing for Sat/Sun. Added disambiguation for that too.
